results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 4 - Green
results.creator_credit: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer and Adem Jaffers
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 4 – Green was broadcast as the fourth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Garry Gallagher (Xmix), Rave Safe, Troubled Waters, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Mad Club (Danny Slim, Susan Clinch, Bernie Grogan & Matt the Tree), Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 4 – Green is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer and Adem Jaffers
results.description:
Please note, this video may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy. Viewer discretion is advised.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 4 – Green was broadcast as the fourth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 4 – Green is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

CREDITS:

Audio and Lights Supplier - LAVA
Props - Voodoo (Phil Woodman), Sioux Dollman
Floor - Kirsten Vinck

PRODUCTION CREW
Producer - Adem Jaffers
Live Producer - Frank Peppard
Web Design - Gary Gallagher, RMIT Computer Centre
Sponsorship - Catherine Carr
Publicity - Sunny Grace
Factbook Design - Melanie Carr
Neolithic Animation - Mandala (Adem Jaffers)
Neolithic Music - Third Eye, The Spiritualist, Void

CONTRIBUTORS

=XMIX=
Animation - Tekhead
Audio - cal-q-lator, “dr. bradford”

22:48:50hrs
“surf - is”

23:05:25hrs

DJ - The Visitor

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part one of two and is titled ‘Festival City’. Wallace and companions travel by car to Adelaide in South Australia, filming the trip as they go.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Festival City’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:02:18:00 ‘Waterfalls Gully’ enroute to Adelaide
00:03:15:00 women posing with their cameras for the filmmaker’s camera.
00:03:39:00 women standing in front of a rock walk before climbing.
00:04:49:00 Adelaide Arts Centre.
00:05:16:00 paddle boats and fountain on the Torrens River in Adelaide.
00:06:31:00 churches in Adelaide.
00:07:09:00 camping alongside a pop-up van.
00:08:06:00 looking at an outdoor art exhibition.
00:09:42:00 sheep in a paddock.
00:10:03:00 historic ‘Peerless Roller Mills’ building in ‘Birdwood’, South Australia.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Innes National Park’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:55:00 campsite including an open fire with ‘billycan’, and a tarpaulin being set up as cover.
00:04:07:00 sign for ‘Innes National Park’
00:04:27:00 sign for ‘Shell Beach’
00:06:15:00 shifting sands in a dune.
00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Orchid Isle’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:23:00 boats and yachts in small harbour.
00:01:36:00 Fijian musicians wearing elaborate floral costumes performing in an outdoor setting.
00:02:10:00 Fijian style thatched houses.
00:03:01:00 turtle swimming.
00:04:55:00 tourists participating in cultural performance.
00:05:35:00 palm weaving being shown to tourists.
00:06:51:00 passengers onboard a ferry listening to local musicians.
00:09:43:00 large ship at port in Suva.
00:10:18:00 local traffic in Suva.
00:10:30:00 marching military band in Suva.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

results.title: History's a snap: Australia as Australians saw it
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Examines the value of the ordinary snapshot over the years and the role it has played in detailing the history of the State of Victoria.
results.title_for_label: History’s a snap: Australia as Australians saw it

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Echuca’, captures a visit to the township of Echuca on the Murray River in Victoria as well as travels along the river itself. Wallace focuses on travelling the river and also on the historic buildings in Echuca itself.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Ehuca’
00:00:20:00 paddle steamer travelling on the Murray River.
00:01:26:00 to 00:02:50:00 historic public buildings and houses around Echuca township
00:01:53:00 historic ‘Log Buggy’ in Echuca which holds a felled log from the nearby Moira Forest
00:03:04:00 steam rollers in Echuca
00:04:22:00 Echuca-Moama Bridge over the Murray River
00:05:02:00 motor traffic and streets in Echuca
00:05:04:00 St Mary’s Catholic Church in Echuca
00:05:39:00 Paddle Steamer Adelaide, berthed as an exhibit in the Hopwood Gardens in Echuca, in the 1960s
00:07:58:00 passengers on a paddle steamer on the river
00:08:55:00 water skiing on the river
00:09:03:00 ‘Weir & Lock No 26’ at Torrumbarry
00:10:07:00 logging and sawmill on the riverbank
00:12:35:00 open fire barbeque and picnic on the riverbank
00:13:59:00 examples of fungi along the river
00:14:50:00 group gathering with guitarist at dusk
